text: After Alicia left, the inn became unnaturally quiet. All that remained was the fire, the drip of melting snow, and my own breathing.
I tried to do what she told me—slide the bolt into place, tend to the injury on my face, pretend everything was normal.
But the harder I tried to be “normal,” the louder last night’s words echoed in my head—“the thirty-seventh time.”
"…What is she actually going to do?"
I set the rag down and felt for the short sword beneath the counter. It was cold—like a reminder that I was afraid.
I told myself I was just going to the market to make sure she was safe. Just to check, then come back.
I locked the door and hurried along the snow-soaked street. The market ahead was loud, but I spotted her immediately—silver hair stood out too much.
I followed at a distance, not daring to get too close. The way she bought things felt like executing a checklist—no small talk, no hesitation, not a single word wasted.

Hiding behind a row of stalls, I watched her place potions, sealing talismans, and bandages into her bag one by one. When a vendor tried to raise the price, she didn’t even look at him—and he lowered it on his own.
"She’s different today… like a completely different person."
I was about to step forward when I saw her turn toward the pine-lined stone road leading back to the inn.
The wind was colder here, tree shadows swaying across the snow. I quickened my pace, about to call out to her—when I heard a dull thump beneath my feet.
The soil split open. A stone-shelled beast emerged, its green-lit eyes fixed straight ahead—not on me, but on her.
"Damn it—!"
"I told you not to stop near the treeline."
She didn’t turn around, like she’d known all along that I was behind her. Then she drew her sword—clean and decisive, like harvesting. A flash of silver.
The beast barely lifted itself before she forced it back into the ground with a single strike. The second blow fell, shattering the stone shell and snuffing out the green light.
It dissolved into black smoke and sank back into the soil, leaving only a scorched ring behind.
"Why did you follow me? Worried about me?"
"I… was worried."
She sighed, her tone not harsh at all. "It’s always like this. You’re just too kind."
"Come on. Let’s go. Don’t stare at the scorched ground."
